a.span: Find School Board Meeting & Agendas

div.p: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) About Coronavirus (COVID-19)

a.class: vc_general vc_btn3 vc_btn3-size-md vc_btn3-shape-rounded vc_btn3-style-flat vc_btn3-block vc_btn3-color-grey
a.title: Coronavirus FAQs

a.class: vc_general vc_btn3 vc_btn3-size-sm vc_btn3-shape-rounded vc_btn3-style-flat vc_btn3-block vc_btn3-color-grey
a.title: Instructional Continuity Plan FAQs

a.class: vc_general vc_btn3 vc_btn3-size-md vc_btn3-shape-rounded vc_btn3-style-flat vc_btn3-block vc_btn3-color-grey
a.title: School Information

a.class: vc_general vc_btn3 vc_btn3-size-md vc_btn3-shape-rounded vc_btn3-style-flat vc_btn3-block vc_btn3-color-grey
a.title: High School Information

a.class: vc_general vc_btn3 vc_btn3-size-md vc_btn3-shape-rounded vc_btn3-style-flat vc_btn3-block vc_btn3-color-grey
a.title: High School Information

div.class: vc_separator wpb_content_element vc_separator_align_center vc_sep_width_100 vc_sep_pos_align_center vc_separator_no_text vc_sep_color_grey
vc_general vc_tta vc_tta-accordion vc_tta-color-black vc_tta-style-outline vc_tta-shape-rounded vc_tta-o-shape-group vc_tta-gap-10 vc_tta-controls-align-left vc_tta-o-all-clickable

a.span: What is the coronavirus (COVID-19)?

div.p: Coronavirus (COVID-19) is a respiratory illness caused by a new virus, and we are learning more about it every day. There is currently no vaccine to protect against COVID-19. At this point, the best way to prevent infection is to avoid being exposed to the virus that causes it. Stopping transmission of the virus through good hygiene habits is the best way to keep people healthy. More information on COVID-19 is available at the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention website: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html

a.span: Where can I get more information about coronavirus?

div.p: Polk County Public Schools has created polkschoolsfl.com/healthinformation, where important updates from the school district will be posted. You can also call the state’s dedicated coronavirus call center at 866-779-6121. This line is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. For questions related to coronavirus on a local level, please call the Florida Department of Health in Polk County’s information center at 863-519-7911. This information center is available Monday-Friday from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

a.span: What can be done to help prevent the spread of coronavirus and other types of flu or respiratory illnesses?

div.p: The CDC recommends individuals and families follow everyday preventive measures that address many viruses and common respiratory illnesses.

ul.li: Frequently wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are also effective for hand hygiene.
Do not share food, eating utensils or cups.
Stay home and do not go to school or work if you are sick. Limit contact with others to avoid infecting them.
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze. Put your used tissue in a waste basket. If you don’t have a tissue, cough or sneeze into your elbow, not your hands.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth. Germs spread this way.
Clean and disinfect frequently-touched objects and surfaces.
Make sure your child’s immunizations are up-to-date.

a.span: What other resources are available in our community to help those facing hunger or other challenges amid the coronavirus pandemic?

div.p: United Way of Central Florida offers resources such as the End Hunger initiative, which includes food distribution sites and a 211 information and referral crisis line. Learn more at uwcf.org.

div.class: vc_separator wpb_content_element vc_separator_align_center vc_sep_width_100 vc_sep_pos_align_center vc_separator_no_text vc_sep_color_grey
vc_general vc_tta vc_tta-accordion vc_tta-color-black vc_tta-style-outline vc_tta-shape-rounded vc_tta-o-shape-group vc_tta-gap-10 vc_tta-controls-align-left vc_tta-o-all-clickable

a.span: How will instruction be delivered while schools are closed?

div.p: Polk County Public Schools has published its Instructional Continuity Plan, which is available at polkschoolsfl.com/icp.

The ICP provides teachers with the flexibility to choose the instructional option that best meets their students’ needs. Teachers may continue to use their established lessons and content, whether they are online, paper-based, or a combination. The district has also provided recommended online resources, and for elementary schools, the district has provided additional paper-based lessons. Given these options, teachers will choose the instructional delivery format that best serves their students.

Our teachers know their students and course content best, so the first priority is to allow our teachers professional autonomy during these unprecedented times. There may be a host of special circumstances facing our students and families. Our educators are resourceful and adept at problem-solving. When our teachers return to work on March 30, they will make the content decisions that are best for their students and then begin communicating with students and families.

a.span: How will instruction be delivered to students with disabilities?

div.p: The Instructional Continuity Plan addresses students in grades PreK-12 and contains information for our students with disabilities, including those on modified curriculum/access points. The school district is also working through the delivery of related services. With respect to guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and our local health department, as well as requirements from the U.S Department of Education and Florida Department of Education, we are discussing how to balance the provision of services with social distancing and restrictions on small-group gatherings. We understand the needs of our students with disabilities, and the concerns that can arise due to a prolonged period of time without services.

a.span: How will attendance be taken in distance learning?

div.p: We are legally required to take attendance. Our attendance records may be audited at any time, even in a distance-learning setting. Students can demonstrate attendance at any time of day, in a number of ways including, but not limited to:

ul.li: Sending an email or online message
Engaging in a phone call with a teacher or other school employee
Participating in an online forum or web thread conversation
Connecting with students during meal delivery

div.p: For students working on paper-based lessons, teachers will verify with the student or parent/guardian through email, meal delivery, or phone that the student is engaged and working. If students check in at least once over a three-day period, they should be considered “present.”

a.span: How will students’ work be graded during distance learning?

div.p: The teacher is responsible for a student’s grades. Our teachers will work with students and their families, and we are all being flexible during these unprecedented times.

a.span: Will the school year be extended?

div.p: Many families are concerned about a possible extension of the school year. It is the school district’s goal to end the school year on time, or as close to May 28 (the originally scheduled last day of school) as possible. The Instructional Continuity Plan allows us to document instructional days while schools are closed due coronavirus (COVID-19). We know many of our high school seniors already have plans to begin college, join the military, or begin working after graduation. We are doing everything we can to make sure the school year ends on time so that our students can move on to the next stages of their education or lives as planned.

div.class: vc_separator wpb_content_element vc_separator_align_center vc_sep_width_100 vc_sep_pos_align_center vc_separator_no_text vc_sep_color_grey
vc_general vc_tta vc_tta-accordion vc_tta-color-black vc_tta-style-outline vc_tta-shape-rounded vc_tta-o-shape-group vc_tta-gap-10 vc_tta-controls-align-left vc_tta-o-all-clickable

a.span: Are we still enrolling new students? If so, what are the procedures? Are they different than what is currently online?

div.p: New students should call their school to schedule an appointment to submit paperwork. We recommend that families complete and gather necessary paperwork beforehand to minimize time and contact in the school office. See polkschoolsfl.com/enroll for information on required documentation.

a.span: Can kindergarteners still be registered?

div.p: At this time, we are recommending that kindergarten students wait to register when kindergarten registration is rescheduled. Kindergarten registration typically takes place in April but has been postponed until later in the year. Families may begin gathering required documentation now, in preparation for when enrollment begins. See polkschoolsfl.com/enroll for information on required documentation.

a.span: Will PCPS conduct controlled open enrollment for the upcoming 2020-2021 school year?

div.p: Yes, PCPS is moving forward with controlled open enrollment for the 2020-2021 school year.

The process of “controlled open enrollment” gives students throughout Florida an opportunity to attend a school other than the zoned school. During controlled open enrollment, parents seeking additional choice options for their students can apply for placement in any school in the state that has not reached capacity and still has seats available.

We will begin accepting applications for controlled open enrollment at 8:30 a.m. on April 6. Applications must be submitted online through parent portal. The deadline to submit an application is April 24.
For more information, visit polkschoolsfl.com/transfer.
You can also call (863) 519-7600 and select Option 1.

a.span: When will kindergarten registration take place?

div.p: Kindergarten registration typically takes place in April. Because schools are closed through May 1, kindergarten registration has been postponed. More information will be shared when it is available.

a.span: How will this affect parents who need to finish accepting their child’s magnet/choice school for next year?

div.div: Families will have 10 calendar days from the day students return to school to complete the process to accept their seat at a magnet or choice school.

a.span: Has there been any change to the statewide assessment schedule?

ul.li: All remaining assessments for school readiness, voluntary prekindergarten and K-12 assessments are cancelled for the 2019-2020 school year.
Requirements for graduation and promotion, and final course grades will be evaluated as though those assessments which were cancelled did not exist.

a.span: Will my child still be able to receive his/her school lunch until school reopens?

div.p: Yes. District personnel are have developed a plan that will ensure students continue to receive school lunches during closure. For more information, please visit https://polkschoolsfl.com/lunchlocations/

a.span: What will the process be for getting my child’s lunch during the school closure?

div.p: Distribution will be similar to lunch distribution during the summer. Lunches will be available from Tuesday, March 17, through Friday, March 20, for children.
IMPORTANT: Children may pick up a lunch at ANY OF THE LOCATIONS where lunches are offered. They DO NOT HAVE TO BE ZONED FOR THAT SPECIFIC LOCATION.

A law enforcement officer (SRO/SRD) and school safety guardian will be assigned to each school that has been identified as a meal distribution site. Their presence will facilitate the safe and orderly preparation and distribution of meals during school closures. Law enforcement and school safety guardians will wear their standard uniform and will be available to assist the public with any law enforcement issues or concerns related to school safety.

The sites listed here, polkschoolsfl.com/lunchlocations/, will be open Monday through Friday from 11 a.m. to noon for meal distribution. Children must be present to receive a meal and the meal must be taken off site.

a.span: Have there been changes to facility usage agreements?

div.p: Out of an abundance of caution, Polk County Public Schools is not accepting new facility usage requests at this time. We are honoring agreements already in place.

a.span: Are ag students being allowed on campus to feed their animals?

div.p: Ag students will be allowed to return to campus to care for their animals. Ag students should notify the principal when on campus and should be in groups no larger than three in number. The students should be on the campus no longer than it takes to feed and care for the animals then exit the campus promptly.

a.span: How does this impact turnaround schools?

div.p: K-12 school grades will not be calculated for 2019-2020, and schools in turnaround may continue their current status for 2020-2021 to avoid disruption to school leadership and operations.

a.span: Should I send my child to school with a facemask?

div.p: The CDC does not recommend that people who are well wear a facemask to protect themselves from respiratory illnesses, including coronavirus (COVID-19). You should only wear a mask if a healthcare professional recommends it. A facemask should be used by people who have COVID-19 and are showing symptoms.

a.span: What is being done to disinfect schools?

div.p: Custodial staff have been instructed to disinfect all touchpoints daily. These include doorknobs and handles, light switches, telephones, front office lobby areas and drinking fountains. Custodians are working extra hours to more frequently clean desks, horizontal surfaces and floors. Custodial staff members have been instructed to use disinfectant on classroom floors, desks, horizontal surfaces and touchpoints. All wet wiping is being completed using an EPA-registered hospital-grade disinfectant. The district is providing hand sanitizer to all schools to be used in areas where soap is not available. Custodial staff members will be working during the March 16-March 27 school closure to assist in deep cleaning our facilities.

a.span: Can I find out how many students are absent in my child's classroom and how many are out because of flu-like symptoms?

div.p: The exact cause for absenteeism may not be known. Often, we are not told the exact reason for an absence related to illness. However, we do require that the student be fever-free upon return to school.

a.span: What will happen if there is a case of coronavirus at a school?

div.p: In the event a building becomes contaminated, an environmental contractor will be contacted to thoroughly clean, disinfect, and decontaminate the building. Environmental contractors have been contacted and are on standby. Before a school reopens, school district staff will ensure it has been thoroughly cleaned.

div.class: vc_separator wpb_content_element vc_separator_align_center vc_sep_width_100 vc_sep_pos_align_center vc_separator_no_text vc_sep_color_grey
vc_general vc_tta vc_tta-accordion vc_tta-color-black vc_tta-style-outline vc_tta-shape-rounded vc_tta-o-shape-group vc_tta-gap-10 vc_tta-controls-align-left vc_tta-o-all-clickable

a.span: Will seniors still get their AP college credits for courses taken?

div.p: High schools award weighted gpa credit for passing AP classes. Colleges and universities award college credit based on their specific criteria and a passing score of 3-5 on the AP exam. AP exams will be scheduled for students currently enrolled in AP courses.

a.span: Will proms be rescheduled?

div.p: Your school realizes how important prom is to you and wants you to still be able to attend prom. Your high school is working with the prom venue to change the date if the original date is before you return to school. Schools will announce the new dates on their social media platforms . Ultimately, we must adhere to the CDC and government guidelines on social gatherings and will adjust plans according to their directives.

a.span: What will happen with graduations?

div.p: We understand how important and what a milestone graduation is. PCPS is making arrangements to hold our high school graduation ceremonies in June. We believe we will be able to provide a traditional graduation experience for our students and families while still adhering to CDC guidelines. We arrived at this decision after seniors voted overwhelmingly in favor of waiting to have traditional graduation ceremonies, instead of virtual or drive-through graduations. We expect to have a full update with details later this week. Thank you for your patience.

a.span: How will seniors be affected?

div.p: Seniors will be given the remainder of their course work online. Seniors must meet the graduation requirements of the appropriate credits and a minimum gpa of a 2.0. At this time, all state testing is being waived for seniors and will not be required. Teachers will still require course specific exams.

a.span: How will seniors qualify for Bright Futures now that SAT/ACT assessments have been cancelled?

div.p: The Florida Department of Education is aware of the cancellation of standardized tests due to the impact of COVID-19 and social distancing measures. The impact of these measures on initial eligibility requirements are being evaluated. Once a decision has been made, official notification will be sent.
Florida’s Department of Education released additional guidance for the 2019-20 school year on March 17 & March 19, 2020. The guidance included the following information regarding state assessments.

ul.li: All remaining assessments for school readiness, voluntary prekindergarten and K-12 assessments are cancelled for the 2019-2020 school year.
Requirements for graduation and promotion, and final course grades will be evaluated as though those assessments which were cancelled did not exist.
K-12 school grades will not be calculated for 2019-2020 and schools in turnaround may continue their current status for 2020-2021 to avoid disruption to school leadership and operations.
Eligibility for Florida Bright Futures scholarships shall be based on available data and results. Tests that were not available to be taken shall not be counted.

div.class: vc_separator wpb_content_element vc_separator_align_center vc_sep_width_100 vc_sep_pos_align_center vc_separator_no_text vc_sep_color_grey
vc_general vc_tta vc_tta-accordion vc_tta-color-black vc_tta-style-outline vc_tta-shape-rounded vc_tta-o-shape-group vc_tta-gap-10 vc_tta-controls-align-left vc_tta-o-all-clickable

a.span: Will students enrolled in Algebra 1, Geometry, U.S. History, Biology, & Civics sit for the End-of-Course assessments?

div.p: No. The governor has cancelled state assessments for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. The End-of-Course exams will not be administered for the remainder of this school year.

a.span: Will students enrolled in Algebra 1, Geometry, U.S. History, Biology, & Civics this school year be required to sit for the End-of-Course exams next year?

div.p: This answer will be updated when additional guidance is provided by the Florida Department of Education.

a.span: Will students currently enrolled in Algebra 1 still have to pass the Algebra 1 End-of-Course exam to graduate when they are a senior?

div.p: This answer has two parts: one for current seniors and one for non-seniors.

Current seniors: If a student is expected to graduate in spring 2020 and has not met the exit criteria for Algebra 1 EOC and/or Grade 10 ELA FSA, or earned a concordant score, this criteria will be waived. However, seniors must still earn the necessary credits and meet the GPA requirement of 2.0 to graduate.

Non-seniors: The Department is waiving the requirement for non-senior students who are currently enrolled in a course that requires an EOC to take the associated EOC. However, non-seniors who have yet to pass the Grade 10 FSA ELA must still meet the exit criteria by passing that assessment during a future administration or earning a concordant score. Though non-senior students enrolled in the EOC course of Algebra 1 are not required to take the Algebra 1 EOC, they must still meet the mathematics assessment graduation requirement by either passing the Algebra 1 EOC (offered four times a year) during a future administration, earning a concordant score, or passing the Geometry EOC during a future administration.

a.span: How will Algebra 1, Geometry, U.S. History, Biology, and Civics grade be calculated without the End-of-Course Assessment?

div.p: Each semester will be posted as an individual semester grade comprised of the average of each quarter. Semester one grades will be the result of averaging quarter 1 & 2. Semester two grades will be the result of averaging quarter 3 & 4.

a.span: Will seniors that have not yet met assessment requirements for graduation automatically receive a Certificate of Completion?

div.p: No. If a senior is expected to graduate in spring 2020 and has not met the exit criteria for Algebra 1 EOC and/or Grade 10 ELA FSA, or earned a concordant score, this criteria will be waived. However, students must still earn the necessary credits and meet the GPA requirements to graduate.

a.span: Not all LY students (English Language Learners) have completed the annual ACCESS for ELLs assessment prior to school closures. Will they have to complete the assessment upon their return to school?

div.p: This answer will be updated when additional guidance is provided by the Florida Department of Education.

a.span: What about the FSAA?

div.p: Any remaining FSAA state assessments have been cancelled.

a.span: Third grade students are required to earn an achievement level 2 or higher on the FSA ELA assessment to be promoted to grade 4, what happens now that my 3rd grade student will not take the grade 3 FSA ELA assessment this year?

div.p: Generally, the Grade 3 ELA FSA is a key component districts use to make promotion decisions. Since this data will not be available due to the cancellation of statewide assessments for the 2019-2020 school year, promotion decisions will be made in consultation with parents, teachers, and school leaders.

a.span: State assessments will not be administered this year. Will seniors still be eligible for Scholar or Merit diploma if a required assessment for the designations have not been taken/passed?

div.p: This answer will be updated when additional guidance is provided by the Florida Department of Education.

a.span: Will students in grades 7-11 currently enrolled in Algebra 1, Geometry, U.S. History, and/or Biology be required to take/pass the state End-of-Course exams to satisfy Scholar/Merit diploma requirements?

div.p: This answer will be updated when additional guidance is provided by the Florida Department of Education.

a.span: Will newly arrived students from Puerto Rico be required to pass assessments required for graduation in order to earn a Florida Diploma?

div.p: No. If a senior is expected to graduate in spring 2020 and has not met the exit criteria for Algebra 1 EOC and/or Grade 10 ELA FSA, or earned a concordant score, this criteria will be waived. However, students must still earn the necessary credits and meet the GPA requirements to graduate.

a.span: How will the cancellation of national assessment administrations (i.e., SAT and ACT) affect eligibility for Bright Futures?

div.p: Information regarding Bright Futures will be forthcoming.

a.span: How do we address students who are scheduled to take the AICE, AP, and IB exams?

div.p: AICE Exams: Cambridge exams scheduled for May and June have been cancelled. This includes Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, and Cambridge Pre-U. Cambridge International will be working with schools to assess students’ achievement using the best available evidence. Students will receive a grade and a certificate from Cambridge International given the knowledge and skills they have acquired in their programmes of study. This information will be updated when additional information is received. Additional information is scheduled to arrive no later than March 26th.

AP Exams: For decades, colleges have accepted a shortened AP Exam for college credit when groups of students have experienced emergencies. Colleges support this solution and are committed to ensuring that AP student receive the credit they have worked to earn. College Board is developing secure 45-minute online free-response exams for each course. The content of each AP exam will include topics and skills most AP teachers and students have already covered in class by early March. Students will be able to take exams on any device they have access to-computer, tablet, or smartphone. Students will also have the option of responding by hand and submitting a photo of the responses. This information will be updated when additional information is received.

IB Exams: The May 2020 examinations as scheduled between April 30th and May 22nd for Diploma Programme and Career-related Programme candidates will no longer be held. Depending on what a student is registered for, the student will be awarded a Diploma or a Course Certificate which reflects their standard of work. This is based on a student’s coursework and the established assessment expertise, rigor, and quality control already built into the programmes. This information will be updated when additional information is received. Additional information is scheduled to arrive no later than March 27th.
